metadata.event_description: Detective puzzle 'Who Let the Frogs Out' by Laird Long

story.full_text: Mr. Womback arrived at his biology classroom at 8:00 am, as usual. Waiting for him in the hallway was Matilda Robbens, one of his eleventh grade students. She was carrying a red and white plastic cooler, the kind you pack picnic lunches in. Only, this cooler seemed to be shaking, all on its own. “I got your frogs, Mr. Womback!” the freckle-faced tomboy yelped, holding up the agitated cooler. “Finally! Thirty frogs, like you wanted.” “Good,” Mr. Womback responded. He unlocked the door to his classroom, flicked on the lights and walked inside. Then he unlocked the door to the storage room behind his front desk. Matilda trailed after him with her jumpy cooler. “Here, put it on the counter, Matilda, next to the aquarium,” Mr. Womback instructed. The girl set the cooler down on the black counter that ran the length of the narrow room, next to a large, empty aquarium. “It took me two whole weeks to catch all of them, Mr. Womback. Like you’ve taught us in class, the frog populations are way down, and I had a really hard time finding all you wanted. Really hard!” “Five dollars a piece, Matilda,” Mr. Womback intoned, opening up the cooler and looking down at thirty healthy green and brown leopard frogs. “As we agreed.” One of the amphibians leaped up and almost hit the man in the nose, and Mr. Womback began transferring the rambunctious hoppers from the cooler to the aquarium. “Ten dollars each,” Matilda countered. Just then Kyle Kravetsky, the science department’s student lab assistant, stuck his head in the doorway. “Here, Kyle,” Mr. Womback said, “help me get these frogs into the aquarium.” “Not a chance, Teach,” Kyle grimaced, watching with distaste as a large green spotted specimen wriggled out of Mr. Womback’s hands and hit the counter hopping. “I’m not touching those slimy reptiles. Snakes, either. You don’t pay me enough for that.” Mr. Womback snorted, grabbing up the rogue frog and squirting it into the aquarium. “Speaking of pay …” Matilda reminded him. “I’m sorry, Matilda. Five dollars per frog is all I have in the budget. I’ll get a check made up that you can pick up in class this afternoon.” It was Matilda’s turn to snort, as she stomped out of the classroom. “Speaking of checks, Mr. W, you think you can advance me my hundred dollars for this week?” Kyle asked. “See, I’ve got a date with-” “You know you left the doors unlocked the other night?” Mr. Womback interrupted, turning on the thin, straw-haired teenager. “Sergio Ramos, the night custodian, informed me that when he came to clean the rooms at 6:00 pm Monday night, both doors were unlocked. I’ve warned you about that before, Kyle. With a key, comes responsibility. We have expensive equipment and toxic chemicals” “Yeah, yeah, sorry about that, Mr. W. Won’t happen again. Now, about that advance …” “See you in class this afternoon,” Mr. Womback dismissed the boy, as he bobbled the last of the squirming frogs into the aquarium. When the biology teacher held up a frog to his eleventh grade class later that afternoon, he announced that they would be dissecting them during Friday’s class. A mixture of cheering and eewing went up, along with Marnie Pepper’s hand. “I protest putting these innocent frogs to death, Mr. Womback!” the small, redheaded bundle of energy stated. As a self-described ‘animal activist’, the girl was concerned with the welfare and ethical treatment of all creatures, amphibious or otherwise. “So noted,” Mr. Womback sighed. “Just like with the worms, Marnie, you can leave the classroom and study a dissection on the computer, while the real dissections are taking place.” Marnie folded her arms over her chest and further declared, “I want it on record that the use of animals for experimental purposes is-” “So noted!” Mr. Womback declared back, sticking the wriggling frog into the pocket of his lab coat. A half hour after class concluded at 3:30, as Mr. Womback was locking his classroom door, he caught Sergio Ramos sauntering down the hallway. “I hope you do a better job of cleaning my class and storage rooms than you did last night, Sergio. Half of the wastepaper baskets weren’t even emptied and some of the lab tables weren’t wiped down. Not to mention, you broke another jar of calf brains.” The lanky janitor glanced angrily around at the students snickering at him getting chewed out by Mr. Womback. “Hey, man,” he said, trying to act cool, “I just came to watch the volleyball game. I’m not on the clock ‘til six, you know.” Mr. Womback grunted. Then he joined the large body of students and teachers heading towards the gymnasium to watch the girls’ volleyball team take on the school’s cross-town rival. Marnie Pepper turned out to be the star of the game, her parents and a crowd of cheering admirers sweeping her and the rest of the team out of the school for a victory party at a local pizzeria right after the game ended at 6:00. Sergio Ramos locked the doors to the school shortly thereafter. Mr. Womback’s first clue that something was wrong the next morning was when he spotted two frogs sitting in a puddle in the teachers’ parking lot. They eyed him suspiciously, and he eyed them. His second clue was when he found both the door to his classroom and his storage room unlocked. His final clue was when he saw the aquarium sitting empty, the window above it slightly ajar. “Morning, Teach,” Kyle Kravetsky said, strolling into the storage room. “Hey, where are all the croakers?” Mr. Womback gritted his teeth. “Apparently, they somehow escaped through a closed window sometime after I left the classroom – locked! – at 4:00 pm yesterday afternoon. Kyle!?” As the teenager blushed redder than a Panamanian poison frog, Matilda Robbens popped her head into the room. “What’s going on? Hey, where’d all the frogs go?” “They were here when I restocked those test tubes around five o’clock like you asked, Mr. W.” Kyle gulped. “I left a little while after that to refill Mr. Ludwig’s Bunsen burners in the chemistry lab. I, uh, think … I locked the doors.” Mr. Womback simmered like pan-fried frogs’ legs, staring at the boy. “Don’t worry, Mr. Womback,” Matilda piped up, “I can get some frogs pretty quick – for a price.” Mr. Womback barged past his two students and out into the classroom proper. His glaring eyes took in the overflowing wastepaper baskets and the puddles of formaldehyde on the lab tables. “Looks like Ramos didn’t even bother cleaning my classroom at all last night!” he growled. Then the irate biology teacher’s blood pressure dropped like a frog’s in winter mud hibernation, as he suddenly realized what happened. “I think I know who let the frogs out,” he hypothesized.

detection.prompt:
System: You are an ingenious and clever detective who will examine all the clues and reason through all the evidence to solve the crime.

User: Here is a detective story. Please read the story carefully before you decide who the culprit is.


Mr. Womback arrived at his biology classroom at 8:00 am, as usual. Waiting for him in the hallway was Matilda Robbens, one of his eleventh grade students. She was carrying a red and white plastic cooler, the kind you pack picnic lunches in. Only, this cooler seemed to be shaking, all on its own. “I got your frogs, Mr. Womback!” the freckle-faced tomboy yelped, holding up the agitated cooler. “Finally! Thirty frogs, like you wanted.” “Good,” Mr. Womback responded. He unlocked the door to his classroom, flicked on the lights and walked inside. Then he unlocked the door to the storage room behind his front desk. Matilda trailed after him with her jumpy cooler. “Here, put it on the counter, Matilda, next to the aquarium,” Mr. Womback instructed. The girl set the cooler down on the black counter that ran the length of the narrow room, next to a large, empty aquarium. “It took me two whole weeks to catch all of them, Mr. Womback. Like you’ve taught us in class, the frog populations are way down, and I had a really hard time finding all you wanted. Really hard!” “Five dollars a piece, Matilda,” Mr. Womback intoned, opening up the cooler and looking down at thirty healthy green and brown leopard frogs. “As we agreed.” One of the amphibians leaped up and almost hit the man in the nose, and Mr. Womback began transferring the rambunctious hoppers from the cooler to the aquarium. “Ten dollars each,” Matilda countered. Just then Kyle Kravetsky, the science department’s student lab assistant, stuck his head in the doorway. “Here, Kyle,” Mr. Womback said, “help me get these frogs into the aquarium.” “Not a chance, Teach,” Kyle grimaced, watching with distaste as a large green spotted specimen wriggled out of Mr. Womback’s hands and hit the counter hopping. “I’m not touching those slimy reptiles. Snakes, either. You don’t pay me enough for that.” Mr. Womback snorted, grabbing up the rogue frog and squirting it into the aquarium. “Speaking of pay …” Matilda reminded him. “I’m sorry, Matilda. Five dollars per frog is all I have in the budget. I’ll get a check made up that you can pick up in class this afternoon.” It was Matilda’s turn to snort, as she stomped out of the classroom. “Speaking of checks, Mr. W, you think you can advance me my hundred dollars for this week?” Kyle asked. “See, I’ve got a date with-” “You know you left the doors unlocked the other night?” Mr. Womback interrupted, turning on the thin, straw-haired teenager. “Sergio Ramos, the night custodian, informed me that when he came to clean the rooms at 6:00 pm Monday night, both doors were unlocked. I’ve warned you about that before, Kyle. With a key, comes responsibility. We have expensive equipment and toxic chemicals” “Yeah, yeah, sorry about that, Mr. W. Won’t happen again. Now, about that advance …” “See you in class this afternoon,” Mr. Womback dismissed the boy, as he bobbled the last of the squirming frogs into the aquarium. When the biology teacher held up a frog to his eleventh grade class later that afternoon, he announced that they would be dissecting them during Friday’s class. A mixture of cheering and eewing went up, along with Marnie Pepper’s hand. “I protest putting these innocent frogs to death, Mr. Womback!” the small, redheaded bundle of energy stated. As a self-described ‘animal activist’, the girl was concerned with the welfare and ethical treatment of all creatures, amphibious or otherwise. “So noted,” Mr. Womback sighed. “Just like with the worms, Marnie, you can leave the classroom and study a dissection on the computer, while the real dissections are taking place.” Marnie folded her arms over her chest and further declared, “I want it on record that the use of animals for experimental purposes is-” “So noted!” Mr. Womback declared back, sticking the wriggling frog into the pocket of his lab coat. A half hour after class concluded at 3:30, as Mr. Womback was locking his classroom door, he caught Sergio Ramos sauntering down the hallway. “I hope you do a better job of cleaning my class and storage rooms than you did last night, Sergio. Half of the wastepaper baskets weren’t even emptied and some of the lab tables weren’t wiped down. Not to mention, you broke another jar of calf brains.” The lanky janitor glanced angrily around at the students snickering at him getting chewed out by Mr. Womback. “Hey, man,” he said, trying to act cool, “I just came to watch the volleyball game. I’m not on the clock ‘til six, you know.” Mr. Womback grunted. Then he joined the large body of students and teachers heading towards the gymnasium to watch the girls’ volleyball team take on the school’s cross-town rival. Marnie Pepper turned out to be the star of the game, her parents and a crowd of cheering admirers sweeping her and the rest of the team out of the school for a victory party at a local pizzeria right after the game ended at 6:00. Sergio Ramos locked the doors to the school shortly thereafter. Mr. Womback’s first clue that something was wrong the next morning was when he spotted two frogs sitting in a puddle in the teachers’ parking lot. They eyed him suspiciously, and he eyed them. His second clue was when he found both the door to his classroom and his storage room unlocked. His final clue was when he saw the aquarium sitting empty, the window above it slightly ajar. “Morning, Teach,” Kyle Kravetsky said, strolling into the storage room. “Hey, where are all the croakers?” Mr. Womback gritted his teeth. “Apparently, they somehow escaped through a closed window sometime after I left the classroom – locked! – at 4:00 pm yesterday afternoon. Kyle!?” As the teenager blushed redder than a Panamanian poison frog, Matilda Robbens popped her head into the room. “What’s going on? Hey, where’d all the frogs go?” “They were here when I restocked those test tubes around five o’clock like you asked, Mr. W.” Kyle gulped. “I left a little while after that to refill Mr. Ludwig’s Bunsen burners in the chemistry lab. I, uh, think … I locked the doors.” Mr. Womback simmered like pan-fried frogs’ legs, staring at the boy. “Don’t worry, Mr. Womback,” Matilda piped up, “I can get some frogs pretty quick – for a price.” Mr. Womback barged past his two students and out into the classroom proper. His glaring eyes took in the overflowing wastepaper baskets and the puddles of formaldehyde on the lab tables. “Looks like Ramos didn’t even bother cleaning my classroom at all last night!” he growled. Then the irate biology teacher’s blood pressure dropped like a frog’s in winter mud hibernation, as he suddenly realized what happened. “I think I know who let the frogs out,” he hypothesized.

Please analyze all the clues and evidence presented in the story and identify who the culprit is. Explain your reasoning step by step, considering:
1. The motives of different characters
2. The opportunities each character had
3. Any physical evidence or alibis
4. The logical deduction from the clues presented

Solve the mystery. Write down your thought process here.

<THOUGHT PROCESS>
<thought process here>
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

Who are the possible suspects? List them here:

<SUSPECTS>
<names(s) for all suspects here, comma separated>
</SUSPECTS>

Who is the culprit (or culprits, if more than one) and why? I want you to distinguish between the main culprit(s) and the accomplices (if any). If there are none, write None. If possible, include first and last names, as well as any aliases. Answer in the form:

<MAIN CULPRIT(S)>
<name(s) here>
</MAIN CULPRIT(S)>

<ACCOMPLICE(S)>
<name(s) here>
</ACCOMPLICE(S)>

Now write down your reconstruction of the events of what actually happened.

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
<event reconstruction here>
</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

Finally, explain why the other suspects are innocent.

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
<explanation here>
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
detection.solution:
<THOUGHT PROCESS>
1.	Who had a reason to get rid of the frogs?
 •	Marnie Pepper – ethical objection to killing animals  
 •	Matilda Robbens – angry that Mr. Womback would only pay $5 instead of the $10 she wanted; if the frogs disappeared he would have to buy them again, perhaps at her new price  
 •	Kyle Kravetsky – no real motive; he just wanted an advance on his pay and has an open dislike of touching frogs  
 •	Sergio Ramos – no motive at all; only annoyed at being yelled at

2.	When could the frogs have been released?  
 •	Kyle sees the frogs “around five o’clock” when he restocks test-tubes.  
 •	Sergio does not start work until 6 p.m.; the room is still dirty the next morning, proving he never entered it that night.  
 Therefore the frogs were released between about 5:15 p.m. and a few minutes before 6 p.m.

3.	Who was free in that 5-to-6 p.m. interval?  
 •	Marnie – on the volleyball court playing the match that ended at 6 p.m.; could not leave the game to slip away.  
 •	Kyle – was in the chemistry lab filling Bunsen-burner bottles and admits he “left a little while after” 5 p.m.; but he hates touching frogs and had just seen them, so if he wanted to release them he would have done it then, not after walking to another lab and coming back.  
 •	Matilda – not on the team, not at the game, and had already shown she could handle frogs easily. She was free to roam the halls.  
 •	Sergio – not yet on duty and said he came only to watch the volleyball game; the dirty classroom shows he never entered after the game.

4.	Physical evidence  
 •	Window over the aquarium is found slightly open — someone opened it deliberately; frogs can’t.  
 •	Classroom and storage-room doors are unlocked the next morning, exactly Kyle’s bad habit; so whoever released the frogs simply took advantage of the doors Kyle had left unlocked.  
 •	Two frogs are already outside in the parking lot, showing they were driven toward the window, not captured for resale.

5.	Logical deduction  
 •	If Sergio never entered, the release had to be before 6 p.m.  
 •	Marnie was on the court; Kyle doesn’t want to touch frogs; only Matilda had both motive (profit/revenge) and freedom of movement.  
 •	Her very first reaction the next morning is an immediate sales pitch: “I can get some frogs pretty quick – for a price.”  She was clearly prepared for exactly this situation.  

Hence Mr. Womback’s sudden insight: it had to be Matilda.
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

<SUSPECTS>
Matilda Robbens, Kyle Kravetsky, Marnie Pepper, Sergio Ramos
</SUSPECTS>

<MAIN CULPRIT(S)>
Matilda Robbens
</MAIN CULPRIT(S)>

<ACCOMPLICE(S)>
None
</ACCOMPLICE(S)>

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
• After school Mr. Womback locks his classroom at 4 p.m. and goes to the gym.  
• About 5:00 p.m. Kyle unlocks the classroom, restocks test tubes in the storage room, sees the frogs, then walks to the chemistry lab, carelessly leaving both doors unlocked as usual.  
• Matilda, upset at receiving only $5 per frog and knowing Kyle often forgets to lock up, checks the room sometime between 5:10 and 5:50 p.m.  
• Finding the doors open, she enters, opens the window above the aquarium, tips or lifts the aquarium so the frogs can hop out, and shoos them toward the window. She then leaves everything as it is (doors still unlocked).  
• The frogs leap out onto the school grounds; two make it as far as the teachers’ parking lot.  
• Matilda returns home, ready to sell “replacement” frogs at a higher price.  
• At 6 p.m. the volleyball match ends; Sergio locks the exterior doors but, being off-duty and still smarting from the earlier scolding, never cleans Mr. Womback’s room, so the mess is untouched.  
• Next morning the unlocked doors, open window, missing frogs and un-emptied trash reveal the timeline to Mr. Womback, who realizes only Matilda had motive and opportunity in the crucial 5-to-6 p.m. window.
</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
• Marnie Pepper – was on court playing volleyball throughout the only available time slot; dozens of spectators (including Mr. Womback) saw her.  
• Kyle Kravetsky – certainly had the opportunity but no motive; moreover he dislikes handling frogs and had just asked Mr. Womback for money, so angering him by destroying his specimens would be self-defeating.  
• Sergio Ramos – did not start work until 6 p.m. and plainly never entered the classroom that night (the room was still dirty). His only interaction with the frogs was being yelled at for an unrelated mess the day before.  
Thus Matilda Robbens is the sole logical culprit.  
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>

original_metadata.answer_options: (a) Kyle Kravetsky; (b) Marnie Pepper; (c) Matilda Robbens; (d) Sergio Ramos
original_metadata.reveal_text:
Matilda Robbens let the frogs out. She gave herself away when she said, “Don’t worry, Mr. Womback … I can get some frogs pretty quick …” Before, she’d told Mr. Womback it had taken her “two whole weeks” to collect thirty frogs, due to the declining frog population. And that should still be the case, unless she knew there were frogs to be found right in the immediate vicinity – where she’d released them the day before.
Kyle Kravetsky’s was not the frog-freer. He’d expressed his aversion to handling “slimy reptiles” earlier (along with his ignorance).
Marnie Pepper couldn’t have released the frogs, because she never had the opportunity. She played in the volleyball game and then left the school immediately afterwards.
And judging from the dirty evidence, Sergio Ramos didn’t even go into Mr. Womback’s classroom or storage room the night before – either to clean them, or play hop-frog out the window.

Now, about that advance …” “See you in class this afternoon,” Mr. Womback dismissed the boy, as he bobbled the last of the squirming frogs into the aquarium. When the biology teacher held up a frog to his eleventh grade class later that afternoon, he announced that they would be dissecting them during Friday’s class. A mixture of cheering and eewing went up, along with Marnie Pepper’s hand. “I protest putting these innocent frogs to death, Mr. Womback!” the small, redheaded bundle of energy stated. As a self-described ‘animal activist’, the girl was concerned with the welfare and ethical treatment of all creatures, amphibious or otherwise. “So noted,” Mr. Womback sighed. “Just like with the worms, Marnie, you can leave the classroom and study a dissection on the computer, while the real dissections are taking place.” Marnie folded her arms over her chest and further declared, “I want it on record that the use of animals for experimental purposes is-” “So noted!” Mr. Womback declared back, sticking the wriggling frog into the pocket of his lab coat. A half hour after class concluded at 3:30, as Mr. Womback was locking his classroom door, he caught Sergio Ramos sauntering down the hallway. “I hope you do a better job of cleaning my class and storage rooms than you did last night, Sergio. Half of the wastepaper baskets weren’t even emptied and some of the lab tables weren’t wiped down. Not to mention, you broke another jar of calf brains.” The lanky janitor glanced angrily around at the students snickering at him getting chewed out by Mr. Womback. “Hey, man,” he said, trying to act cool, “I just came to watch the volleyball game. I’m not on the clock ‘til six, you know.” Mr. Womback grunted. Then he joined the large body of students and teachers heading towards the gymnasium to watch the girls’ volleyball team take on the school’s cross-town rival. Marnie Pepper turned out to be the star of the game, her parents and a crowd of cheering admirers sweeping her and the rest of the team out of the school for a victory party at a local pizzeria right after the game ended at 6:00. Sergio Ramos locked the doors to the school shortly thereafter. Mr. Womback’s first clue that something was wrong the next morning was when he spotted two frogs sitting in a puddle in the teachers’ parking lot. They eyed him suspiciously, and he eyed them. His second clue was when he found both the door to his classroom and his storage room unlocked. His final clue was when he saw the aquarium sitting empty, the window above it slightly ajar. “Morning, Teach,” Kyle Kravetsky said, strolling into the storage room. “Hey, where are all the croakers?” Mr. Womback gritted his teeth. “Apparently, they somehow escaped through a closed window sometime after I left the classroom – locked! – at 4:00 pm yesterday afternoon. Kyle!?” As the teenager blushed redder than a Panamanian poison frog, Matilda Robbens popped her head into the room. “What’s going on? Hey, where’d all the frogs go?” “They were here when I restocked those test tubes around five o’clock like you asked, Mr. W.” Kyle gulped. “I left a little while after that to refill Mr. Ludwig’s Bunsen burners in the chemistry lab. I, uh, think … I locked the doors.” Mr. Womback simmered like pan-fried frogs’ legs, staring at the boy. “Don’t worry, Mr. Womback,” Matilda piped up, “I can get some frogs pretty quick – for a price.” Mr. Womback barged past his two students and out into the classroom proper. His glaring eyes took in the overflowing wastepaper baskets and the puddles of formaldehyde on the lab tables. “Looks like Ramos didn’t even bother cleaning my classroom at all last night!” he growled. Then the irate biology teacher’s blood pressure dropped like a frog’s in winter mud hibernation, as he suddenly realized what happened. “I think I know who let the frogs out,” he hypothesized.
puzzle_data.answer_options: (a) Kyle Kravetsky; (b) Marnie Pepper; (c) Matilda Robbens; (d) Sergio Ramos
puzzle_data.outcome:
Matilda Robbens let the frogs out. She gave herself away when she said, “Don’t worry, Mr. Womback … I can get some frogs pretty quick …” Before, she’d told Mr. Womback it had taken her “two whole weeks” to collect thirty frogs, due to the declining frog population. And that should still be the case, unless she knew there were frogs to be found right in the immediate vicinity – where she’d released them the day before.
Kyle Kravetsky’s was not the frog-freer. He’d expressed his aversion to handling “slimy reptiles” earlier (along with his ignorance).
Marnie Pepper couldn’t have released the frogs, because she never had the opportunity. She played in the volleyball game and then left the school immediately afterwards.
And judging from the dirty evidence, Sergio Ramos didn’t even go into Mr. Womback’s classroom or storage room the night before – either to clean them, or play hop-frog out the window.
